detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value: Restricted to BMUS COMP majors only.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
Open to graduate non-composition music major students, only, by permission of instructor and submission of scores. Weekly tutorial instruction will be scheduled.

Non-composition majors in 307 also will be expected to attend the Monday noon composition seminars.

For permission to register, contact Dr. Dorothy Chang at dorothy.chang(at)ubc.ca.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value: 309 is open to BA music majors or other students, if they have completed MUSC 200. Second-year BMUS composition majors are exempt from the pre-requisites. Contact instructor if you have questions about your qualifications to register. To possibly fill any current or future vacancy in the class, please register for the waitlist.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value: Conducting courses MUSC 311, MUSC 312, and MUSC 313 are required for BMUS students majoring in GSEM, GSSM, and COMP. Other students interested in taking the course can sign up online to the waitlist. In late July, waitlisted students will receive an application form to fill out which includes rationale for taking the course.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value: Prerequisite: MUSC 119 and one of MUSC 100 or MUSC 103. Permission of instructor is also required.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value: Prerequisite: MUSC 119 and one of MUSC 100 or MUSC 103. Permission of instructor is also required.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
This is a course intended to increase students’ knowledge of popular music history, most particularly in North America from approximately 1900-present. In this course, students will learn not only of significant artists, bands, movements, genres, labels, etc., but also of music analysis. At the end of the course, students should be able to discuss with some fluency the social, political, cultural, and musical forces that have resulted in the current-day popular music landscape. Throughout the course, students will also learn some information about musical instruments, music production software, basic music theory, and other relevant concepts.

Students are not required to have a musical background. All musical concepts will be introduced in class.

This course cannot count towards the BMUS or the BA Major or Minor in Music.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value: This course introduces students to the music cultures of the world with emphasis on the similarities and differences in performance practices associated with each geo-cultural location. The course is a survey of the different music traditions of the world, in which music is explored as an expression of cultural identity and as an aesthetic experience. It is a flexible exploration of music in terms of its cultural, aesthetic, political, and economic dimensions - all concerns of Ethnomusicology. It employs a performance and functional approach to studying the diversity and contexts of different musical traditions focusing on topical issues including politics, performance, gender, ethnicity, and religion. The geo-cultural areas to be studied include Africa (Ghana. Mali, Zimbabwe), The Americas (Native North, Central and South America), Europe, and Asia (India and Indonesia). Musical genres include, but are not limited to, folk, court, ritual, popular, art/classical, and narrative traditions from selected music cultures of the above geo-cultural areas. The course intends to develop an understanding for a variety of music in the world through lectures, lecture demonstration and discussion, audio-visual presentations, workshops, and if possible, live performances.This course is open to all students, and may be taken for credit toward the B.Mus. and the B.A. in Music.

instances.text: MUSC_V 340-001 - Piano Pedagogy I: Theory and Studio Management

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value: Offered in even academic years (alternates with 440). Registration restricted to BMUS students; others may take it with permission of the instructor.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value: BMUS PIAN students register in MUSC 361A in their upper years.For 3rd and 4th year undergraduates (see MUSC 161A for 1st and 2nd year registration).Applied Performance studies in small chamber music ensembles for piano and other instruments. This course is required for PIAN majors in 3rd and 4th year.Groups will be formed in September by course coordinator, and coaching times will then be assigned during the hours indicated on this schedule. Please keep as many of those specified hours open for 361 as possible in your personal course schedule. In addition to coachings, each ensemble should also schedule regular rehearsal time(s) during these hours.Students registered in MUSC 361A who also wish to register in MUSC 457 (Early Music Ensembles) or MUSC 463 (Contemporary Players) may do so, but will need to contact the Music Advisor (music.advisor@ubc.ca) for a registration override. Students seeking additional chamber ensemble credit may be able to add a separate course number (369) in September, pending approval from the Division.Permission to enroll is not guaranteed for BMUS General Music students with a concentration in Piano. General Music piano concentrators generally take applied Chamber Music only once. However, if they have obtained a minimum grade of 88 in MUSC 161 they may apply for a second year of piano chamber studies.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value: Wind Chamber EnsemblesOpen only to 3rd and 4th year students (see MUSC 162A for 1st and 2nd year registration)OPEN TO NON-MUSIC STUDENTS: How do I register for ensembles? For most ensembles an audition is required to secure your place. During the audition you play or sing a prepared piece for the conductor. Auditions for ensembles take place at the beginning of each academic year. https://music.ubc.ca/about/student-ensembles/

Boolean logic can be expressed using AND, OR, NOT, and (). 
Exact phrases can be surrounded by double quotation marks. 
Example: ("software engineer" OR computer science) AND ~manager~.
